abstracts.cdata!:
The Community Infrastructure Development
            project for Jordan had the following ratings: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank performance was satisfactory and the borrower
            performance was highly likely. The lessons learned indicate
            that the coordination by Ministry of Planning and
            International Cooperation (MOPIC) of a multi-donor project
            was crucial to the success of the Community Infrastructure
            Project (CIP). The transparent procurement process and the
            timely payments to contractors led to substantial savings.
            Selecting clear performance indicators for both outputs and
            outcomes from the onset of the project would have helped to
            monitor the targeting of activities and re-focus them when
            circumstances required. Under Part B, sub-projects were
            implemented throughout the life of the project based on the
            initial needs assessment. This, together with the limited
            menu of infrastructure improvements financed under the
            project (mostly roads), created some rigidity during the
            final stages of implementation, somehow reducing the ability
            of the project to target the poorest communities. CIP
            provided models of two types of Bank project assistance: the
            clearly defined, pre-set menu of infrastructure investments
            for the upgrading squatter settlements and refugee camps,
            and the demand-driven approach under component B. The
            Bank-wide implementation profile for similar infrastructure
            projects is substantially in excess of the project period of
            three and a half years. It is important to make realistic on
            the experience of comparable projects and the country situation.
